(西東京市) is a city in

Nishitokyo is located in western Tokyo, about 30 minutes by train from Shinjuku.  Like much of western Tokyo, it's largely residential, with businesses concentrated around the train stations.  The area has a lot of small parks and trees, in contrast with central Tokyo, which has skyscrapers and a lot more concrete.
The only train line running through the city is the Seibu Shinjuku Line (西武新宿線), which ends in Shinjuku to the east and Hon-Kawagoe to the west.

content=This tall tower is perhaps the only iconic landmark in Nishitokyo.  At night, it lights in varying colors.

content=This ice rink has ice hockey and public skating.  On weekends, there are very limited public skating hours, so calling in advance to check on open skating times is recommended.

content=This twelve kilometer bike and pedestrian path begins along the southern edge of Nishitokyo, runs fairly straight NW, and terminates far to the NW at two reservoirs.  It makes for a nice walk or leisurely bike ride of any desirable length.

The best shopping in Nishitokyo is found around the north side of Tanashi Station, where there are several department stores and many other shops.

value: directions=In south-central Nishitokyo, along the border with Musashino.
content=A popular chain store selling a little bit of everything.
directions=In the basement of the Seibu department store just north of Tanashi Station.
content=This shop has best selection of foreign food in Nishitokyo.

Restaurants are found in concentration near Tanashi Station.

content=This beer hall has many international beers in the bottle and a few on tap.  The food is well-prepared pub fare.  The place is clean, and there are several big-screen TVs showing sports.
content=City Hall has essential for long-term residents of the city.  Important information is available in Japanese and (on paper) in English.
